Justification: To assess for any visible abnormalities, such as asymmetry, deformities, or signs of distress.
To identify any areas of tenderness, crepitus, or abnormal masses.
To evaluate for any abnormal heart sounds, murmurs, or signs of heart failure.
To check for any abnormal lung sounds, such as wheezing, crackles, or decreased breath sounds.
To monitor blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and temperature for any changes.
To rule out any abdominal causes of chest pain, such as referred pain from gastrointestinal issues.
To evaluate circulation and check for any signs of peripheral vascular disease.
To assess for signs of heart failure or fluid overload.
To assess for any neurological deficits that may indicate a more serious condition.
To check for diaphoresis, pallor, or any rashes that may indicate systemic issues.
